user.biography: News and analysis with a global perspective. We’re here to help you understand the world around you. Click to learn more about any post 👇

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
More than 50 countries around the world have pledged to become net zero. But what does net zero actually mean—and is it achievable?

Cover image credit: Brandon Thibodeaux/ The New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
The world’s animals and wildlife are going extinct at a greater rate than at any time in human history. Can technology help turn the tide?

Cover image credit: Yashpal Rathore/Nature Picture Library

node.title: Mass extinction: what can stop it?

node.text: Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies set out to upend the financial order and replace conventional money. Bitcoin has certainly disrupted the global financial system, but can it ever live up to the hype? Cover credit: Jakub Porzycki/Getty Images

node.text:
Trophy hunting sparks outrage around the world. But the highly controversial sport can actually help to protect some of Africa's most endangered big animals. Here's how.

Credit: Alamy

node.title: How trophy hunting can protect Africa's wildlife

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Business Billions are pouring into the business of decarbonisation'.

node.text:
Wall Street giants and corporate titans are betting on climate innovation.⁠
⁠
New patents related to core technologies like batteries, hydrogen, smart grids and carbon capture are far outpacing those in other technologies, including fossil fuels.⁠
⁠
Money has followed the innovation. Last year investors poured more than $500bn into the “energy transition”, twice as much as in 2010.⁠
⁠
And between 2013 and 2020 venture capital investments in climate tech grew at five times the rate of global startup funding overall. In 2021 these investments may near $60bn in America alone, up from $36bn last year.⁠
⁠
Can this boom give rise to a new blockbuster industry? To read why the modern climate-tech business looks fit and financially sustainable, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @d_urbo_design

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 17, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
⁠When Kabul fell to the Taliban, less than 24 hours after President Ashraf Ghani visited the edge of the capital to inspect its defences, it was inevitable that people would try to flee.⁠
⁠
The image that people will remember will be that of an air force transport plane taking off with desperate Afghans clinging to its undercarriage, from which they fell to their deaths.⁠
⁠
The airport is now the only part of the city not held by the militants. Instead, it is defended by several thousand American and other foreign troops, many flown in specifically for the evacuation. ⁠
⁠
Over the coming weeks, the evacuation could lift away tens of thousands of people. And though they have not hindered the evacuation flights, Taliban soldiers are reported to be checking people trying to get into the airport, and preventing many from leaving the country. Thousands of Afghans who might be accepted to fly remain in hiding, wondering if they will be able to escape.⁠
⁠
The last-minute panic to rescue interpreters and others who have worked for foreign armies could have been avoided. Tap the link in our bio to read more.⁠
⁠
Credit: AP Photo/Shekib Rahmani

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 17, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
As a ﬁrm socialist, Sir Graham Vick was sickened by the ever-widening gap between rich and poor. He believed with a passion that opera, like all music, belonged to everyone. ⁠
⁠
As a director, he wanted to tear down barriers and bring in the young, uneducated and ignored—like the teenagers he had seen once in Italy, listening  entranced, when he threw the doors of an airless opera house open to the street.⁠
⁠
Sir Graham worked hard in the grandest places. At the New York Met he directed “Il Trovatore”, and at Covent Garden in 1990 his “Falstaﬀ” opened the refurbished house. ⁠
⁠
He was also the ﬁrst director in Britain to cast a black tenor, Ronald Samm, as the lead in Verdi’s “Otello”.⁠
⁠
Click the link our bio to read our obituary of Sir Graham, who has died, aged 67.⁠
⁠
Credit: David Sillitoe / Eyevine

Excluding Germany Sources: Global Power Plant Database; Our World in Data 19 The Economist'.

node.text:
European countries that produce nuclear power emit consistently lower levels of carbon dioxide than those that do not. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Germany wants to be carbon neutral by 2045, but relies heavily on fossil fuels for electricity and heating. So why is it shutting its nuclear plants?⁠⁠
⁠⁠
After a tsunami hit the Fukushima reactor in northern Japan, causing a nuclear disaster, Germany decided to phase out its 12 nuclear power stations.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Now the country wants others to follow its example. But as the second chart shows, few are listening. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Of the 17 European countries producing nuclear energy, only Britain has plans to close any plants soon, and it is still building new ones. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Well-regulated nuclear power is safe, and provides a stable source of emissions-free stability. But to read why the idea of a nuclear reversal remains too toxic for most of Germany’s politicians, click on the link in our bio.

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 17, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Haiti is amazingly resilient.. but it's hard to be positive about recovery Sarah Birke On "ThIn" "The Intelligence"'.

node.text:
A president’s assassination, a cratered economy and now this: a tropical depression that will hamper rescue efforts after a massive earthquake. ⁠
⁠
Haiti cannot catch a break. Today, Tropical Depression Grace will bring rains that may cause flooding and mudslides.⁠
⁠
Haiti now fears what may come from above as it reels from what happened below—at a time when the political situation on the ground represented its own disaster. ⁠
⁠
On "The Intelligence" podcast, our correspondent charts the country's compounded miseries. Tap the link in our bio to listen

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 16, 2021. May be an illustration.

node.text:
When the Taliban withdrew from Kandahar in 2001, one of the most visible signs of change was the sight of girls traipsing through the streets in school uniform on their way to class. ⁠
⁠
Sahar was one of them: she went on to become a doctor at the local hospital. She used to wear jeans to work and paint her nails in bright colours.⁠
⁠
But now that the Taliban are in charge of Afghanistan’s second city, she isn’t sure she’ll be allowed to carry on working. She has already started to wear her mother’s old burqa.⁠
⁠
“It is really hard for me to accept what others choose for me to wear,” says Sahar in @1843mag. “But we have no choice other than to obey whoever rules us.”⁠
⁠
While some women buy burqas, some men are growing their beads long. Others are deleting music and videos from their phones. ⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read how Kandaharis are adjusting to life under the Taliban.⁠
⁠
Credit: Ewelina Karpowiak

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'EXIT'.

node.text:
⁠There is an old joke that the key to success in life is sincerity. If you are not, then you can fake it till you make it.⁠
⁠
Bartleby has found this to be far from the truth. Instead the key to surviving work is flexibility.⁠
⁠
Employees are expected to learn how to use, or at least understand new jargon even when it seems fatuous or irritating.⁠
⁠
Even during the pandemic, workers have had to show more flexibility, keeping in touch with their colleagues and maintaining their productivity while juggling child care and the need to avoid infection.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read the latest and final Bartleby by our correspondent before he retires. ⁠
⁠
Illustration: @paulyblow

node.text:
Drought almost seems too puny a word to describe the water scarcity that America's south-west is experiencing. ⁠
⁠
A white strip more than 150 feet tall encircles the turquoise surface of Lake Mead, America’s largest reservoir, showing visitors how high the water once was, and how far it has fallen.⁠
⁠
Perhaps no place is more spooked by Lake Mead’s decline than the Las Vegas valley (pictured), which gets 90% of its water from the nearby reservoir. ⁠
⁠
The valley cut its water use by 23% since 2002 while adding about 800,000 residents to its population.⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to to find out why the region’s future could be hotter and drier still.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on August 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'International travel may not return to normal until 2024 Global airline passenger bookings January 7th 2020=100, seven-day moving average 140 120 100 Domestic 80 60 40 20 International 2020 Source: ATA DDS -20 2021 The Economist'.

node.text:
Struggling to book a trip overseas? You’re not alone. ⁠
⁠
Governments have succeeded in taking the joy out of foreign travel with rules that are arbitrary, unpredictable and constantly changing.⁠
⁠
All of this means travel will remain out of reach for many and messy for all, for some time. ⁠
⁠
The chaos is unlikely to subside soon, as new covid-19 outbreaks emerge and governments struggle to coordinate policy.⁠
⁠
A less open world means less freedom—and the pandemic will disrupt travel for years to come. To read why daft rules could end up sticking around for even longer, click on the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Haiti. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text:
⁠Haiti’s government is struggling to deal with the aftermath of a 7.2-magnitude earthquake that struck on Saturday. ⁠
⁠
The tremor was stronger than the deadly quake that killed over 200,000 people in 2010. ⁠
⁠
Currently, the confirmed death toll is over 1,000, and is likely to increase further. Thousands more are injured and many are still missing. ⁠
⁠
The country has been in political turmoil since the assassination of Jovenel Moïse, the then-president, on July 7th. Gangs, who control several key neighbourhoods in, and roads to, the capital, Port-au-Prince, will make it harder to transport much-needed supplies, including shelter, food and water, to the hardest hit areas.⁠
⁠
Take five minutes to catch up on this and other essential news stories from today. Click on the link in our bio to read our daily briefing.⁠
⁠
Credit: Reuters/Ralph Tedy Erol

node.text:
Afghanistan is now squarely under Taliban rule, as it was when America first invaded 20 years ago. ⁠
⁠
This morning, the Taliban released a video claiming a "great victory", congratulating the people of Kabul on their new leadership and claiming now is the time to give serenity to the nation.⁠
⁠
On "The Intelligence" podcast, we ask our defence editor what Taliban control will mean for the people of Afghanistan at large. He explains that people like 20-year-old Muhammad Yusun feel that their lives have now been upturned.⁠
⁠
To learn more about how Afghanistan got to this point, and the country's fate, tap the link in our bio to listen to the podcast.
